sub_title: Environmental Engineer @ Van Oord | MSc. TU Delft
summary:
I am currently part of the environmental engineering team within Van Oord's Engineering and Estimation division. My work primarily focuses on analyzing and mitigating underwater acoustics related to Van Oord's offshore wind projects. 

I have a Master of Science from the Faculty of Aerospace Engineering, TU Delft. My studies were centered around aerodynamics, aeroelasticity, and wind energy.

projects.title: Wake Dynamics of a Cylinder with a Splitter Plate
projects.description:
Master Thesis Project
Grade: 7.5/10

Energy harvesters have been a new avenue to generate electrical energy locally for remote applications, but their flow mechanisms under different conditions have not been fully understood. This work aims to bridge this gap by characterizing the mechanisms and wake dynamics of a cylinder with a flexible splitter plate. Measurements are made at different flow speeds to characterize the behavior of the wake, and Helium Filled Soap Bubbles (HFSB) are used in flow diagnostic tools such as Lagrangian Particle Tracking (LPT) experiments. Shake-The-Box (STB) is a novel LPT tracking algorithm that uses time-resolved experimental data to predict future tracer particle locations. The raw experimental data was processed to perform statistical analysis, proper orthogonal decomposition, and spectral analysis to provide insights to meet the thesis objective.

contributors.headline: Environmental Engineer @ Van Oord | MSc. TU Delft

projects.title: Wind Farm Layout Optimization Problem using Greedy and Random Search Algorithms
projects.description:
Course: Engineering Optimization - Concepts & Applications
Grade: 6/10

Typically, wind power is harvested using wind farms, where multiple wind turbines are placed in proximity to each other. The proper design of a wind farm is crucial in maximizing the power output (and hence, the cost-effectiveness) of the farm. Owing to the fact that wind turbines generate electricity by disrupting the airflow in their vicinity, the wind turbines downstream receive wind at lower speeds than the upstream turbines. Given the constraints, there is an optimal solution of a wind farm that produces the maximum power. This solution is arrived at by implementing greedy and random search algorithms.

projects.title: Numerical Unsteady Blade Element Momentum Theory implementation with Dynamic Stall
projects.description:
Course: Wind Turbine Aeroelasticity
Grade: 8/10

Implementing a simplified version of the Beddoes-Leishman model for dynamic stall to an unsteady blade element momentum (BEM) code. The Beddoes-Leishman model contains four components or modules, the unsteady attached flow module, non-linear trailing edge separation module, leading edge separation module, and the vortex shedding and lift module. These components model the physics of the response of an unsteady airfoil with pitching or heave instabilities.

projects.title: Numerical Unsteady Blade Element Momentum Theory implementation with Dynamic Inflow
projects.description:
Course: Wind Turbine Aeroelasticity
Grade: 8/10

Modifying quasi-steady Blade Element Momentum theory to account for unsteady inflow that is modeled using dynamic inflow models namely Pitt-Peters, Oye, and Larsen Madsen. The code is developed using Python and implemented for a step and sinusoidal variations of thrust coefficient and freestream velocity

projects.title: Navier Stokes Solver based on Incidence and Hodge Matrices
projects.description:
Course: CFD II: Discretization Techniques
Grade: 8/10

Writing a solver for the Navier-Stokes equations applied to a lid-driven cavity problem. The solver is based on the use of incidence and Hodge matrices.  The domain is discretized into N x N grid, also known as the primal mesh, which contains information about the velocity fluxes. Associated with this primal mesh we have a dual grid that contains unknowns related to the pressure.

projects.title: Stability Analysis and Gust Response of a Typical Section
projects.description:
Course: Fundamentals of Aeroelasticity
Grade: 9/10

Developing state-space model equations for a typical section with pitch and heave degrees of freedom in the realm of Theordoresen Aerodynamics. A typical section is the model cross-section of the wing that can be considered to be representative of the entire wing. The state-space model was then subject to an eigenvalue analysis to test the wing's stability characteristics and flutter speed. The state-space model was later simulated for a 1-cos gust of varying lengths to assess the wing response and onset of limit cycle oscillations if applicable.

contributors.headline: Environmental Engineer @ Van Oord | MSc. TU Delft

projects.title: Wind Tunnel Flow Measurement using Hot Wire Anemometry and Particle Image Velocimetry
projects.description:
Course: Flow Measurement Techniques
Grade: 7.5/10

Wind tunnel flows measurement and quantification using Hot Wire Anemometry (HWA) and Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV). Experimental data set processed on MATLAB. HWA is a flow measurement technique that uses a heated wire probe that is introduced into the flow. The wire subject to the flow is then cooled, the corresponding voltage necessary to maintain the temperature of the flow can be used to quantify the flow velocity. On the other hand, PIV is an imaging based technique where a small section of the flow is illuminated using lasers. A high-speed camera then captures successive images of the flow, which can then be used to find average displacement using cross-correlation. Using the pulse width separation of the laser and average displacement using cross-correlation, the flow contours can be reconstructed using interrogation windows.

projects.title: Aerodynamics Analysis of a Propeller Blade
projects.description:
Course: Aircraft Aerodynamics 
Grade: 8/10

Propeller propulsion systems are known to be very fuel-efficient compared to jet turbofan engines provided the operational Mach number is not too high (M<0.7). This is the major reason why so-called “open rotor” systems and distributed propeller systems are regarded as the next step towards more efficient, green, aircraft. In this chapter, we aim to introduce the major characteristics of propellers and ways to estimate their performance characteristics. 

The assignment is divided into three parts, namely; 
- Multi-Element Airfoil Analysis: Analyzing different phenomena associated with rotor systems, namely velocity diagrams, axial and tangential flow over the blades, and Prandtl tip loss factors.
- Comparing experimental results to the results produced by a flow solver called Javaprop. 
- Understanding the effects of the number of blades and blade radius on the propeller system.

projects.title: Design of Airfoil and Boundary Layer Transition Analysis Using XFoil
projects.description:
Course: Aircraft Aerodynamics 
Grade: 8/10

The aerodynamic characteristics and performance of any aircraft part exposed to the external flow is significantly influenced by the state of the boundary layer (BL), that can either be laminar or turbulent. To determine in how far the BL transition on a 2D airfoil is affected by its shape and the atmospheric turbulence scale, this assignment addresses the airfoil design in relation to the transition point location.
The project is divided into three parts, namely; 

- Airfoil Analysis: Analyzing a NACA airfoil on XFOIL. Plotting the lift and drag polar, change in transition point along the chord, etc. 
- Airfoil Improved Design: Optimizing chosen NACA airfoil to improve the glide ratio. This is also done manually in XFOIL. 
- Laminar Separation Bubble: At low Reynolds numbers the airfoil may develop a so-called laminar separation bubble. This has consequences for the drag and the stall behavior of the airfoil. The goal of this task is to understand the nature and effects of the bubble.

projects.title: Developing a Vortex Panel Method Code for Thin and Cambered Airfoil Implementation
projects.description:
Course: Aircraft Aerodynamics 
Grade: 8/10

The goal of this task is to write a clear and concise program that is able to calculate the pressure distribution (dCp/(x/c)) and the lift coefficient of planar and cambered airfoils with zero thickness according to a numerical approximation of the Thin Airfoil Theory. The code was written in Matlab. The solver is based on a discrete vortex distribution over a paneled cambered airfoil. Other tasks in this assignment include:

- Discussing key equations and parameters is utilized.
- Comparing a symmetric and a cambered airfoil in terms of the list polar and the pressure distributions 
- Analyzing the effects of panel density on the nature of the results 
- Differences between thick and thin airfoils and the effects it has on the lift gradient

projects.title: Multi-Element Airfoil Analysis using Javafoil
projects.description:
Course: Aircraft Aerodynamics 
Grade: 8/10

Multi-element airfoils play a key role in attaining high performance in the take-off and landing conditions of aircraft. The design of systems with leading edge and trailing edge devices is complicated due to the strong interaction effects between the different elements. The analysis of multi-element airfoil systems can be difficult due to limited accuracy with flow separation models, the possibility of wake bursting, and compressibility.
The assignment is divided into three parts, namely; 

- Multi-Element Airfoil Analysis: Analyzing different phenomena associated with multi-element airfoils, namely working principles of slats and flaps, wake bursting phenomenon, and effects of a high-lift system. 
- Comparing experimental results to the results produced by a potential flow solver called Javafoil. 
- Canonical Pressure Distribution and Gartshore condition: Investigating the canonical pressure distributions of a multi-element airfoil set up including the Gartshore condition.

projects.title: Implementing Prandtl Lifting Line Theory Numerically for Single and Multiple Wind Turbines
projects.description:
Course: Rotor and Wake Aerodynamics
Grade: 7.5/10

The lifting line theory is a mathematical theory that predicts the distribution of lift over a wing. This theory is also called the Lanchester-Prandtl lifting line theory in honor of the people who independently came up with the model.

The goal of this assignment is to numerically implement the lifting line theory to the wind turbine blades that are pre-defined. We then analyze the results of the model based on parameters such as radial distributions of angles of importance, circulation, and loads across a single rotor. We also compare the interaction between two rotors spaced at different distances from each other.

projects.title: Unsteady Aerodynamics of Thin Airfoils (Flat Plate) in a 2D Potential Flow
projects.description:
Course: Rotor and Wake Aerodynamics
Grade: 7.5/10

Natural winds are often unsteady in their strength, direction or both. It takes a finite time for the wind to travel from far upwind of a rotor to far downwind and in that time wind conditions will change, so an equilibrium state is rarely achieved. Small-scale turbulence will cause a continuous unsteadiness in the velocities impinging on a rotor blade/airfoil.

We aim to study the effects of this unsteady flow by modelling flow cases and implementing it numerically on a two dimensional thin airfoil modelled by vortex panels. The following flow cases are studied: Steady flow at different angles of attack, Pitching airfoil at different reduced frequencies, Steady airfoil with flap at different amplitude, Unsteady airfoil with flap at different amplitudes and reduced frequencies, Unsteady airfoil under gust, Unsteady airfoil in blade vortex interaction.

projects.title: Winglet Analysis and Design
projects.description:
Course: Aircraft Aerodynamics 
Grade: 8/10

Beginning with the early work of Whitcomb, winglets have been utilized over the past decades for improving aircraft aerodynamic efficiency. In general, a winglet produces a force, which has a forward component because of the normal wash produced by the circulation over the wing tip. This forward component acts as a thrust force reducing the aircraft-induced drag, which is about 40% of the total drag in the cruise and 80–90% of the total drag in the second climb segment. Although adding a winglet to a wing may be attractive from the perspective of aerodynamic performance it also affects the wing's structural weight.
Therefore, a pure aerodynamic optimization may result in a winglet with an unacceptable weight penalty. This additional weight may alleviate the beneficial effect of drag reduction. Hence, the design of a non-planar wing is a real multidisciplinary design optimization process. 

The assignment is divided into three parts, namely; 
- The first part discusses the effects of the winglet on the induced drag and normal wash velocity.
- The second part of the assignment assesses the effects of cant angle of the induced drag and bending moment, etc. 
- The last part of the assignment optimizes the wing/let system by reducing the objective function.

projects.title: Discount Airlines: Are Low Cost Carriers the Sustainable Future of Aviation?
projects.description:
Course: Engineering Ethics 
Grade: 7.5/10

The cost of running an airline business profitably is a delicate affair, especially in the modern age where value creation is held in high regard. The delicate balance between profit and loss implies that very few airlines recover their invested capital. In such a cut-throat competition market, low-cost carriers has been an enduring phenomenon. Low cost carriers (LCC) emphasize on reducing operational costs while maximizing profits. This is achieved but cutting all additional amenities and focusing on core customer needs only. 

This minimum cost model, however, has brought certain environmental and social challenges. Apart from the obvious emissions of the aircraft, the LCCs are growing faster than the aviation industry is in general, and therefore also faster than the infrastructure intended for aviation. This means that new airport constructions are needed, and existing airports are running overtime to accommodate the traffic. Socially, it is seen that the economic benefit gained locally due to the increase in travel is not universally applicable, which means that all regions might not see the promised growth from the new LCC routes and airports. LCCs also pose ethical questions in their treatment of employees. The morality of the LCC model is analyzed using the ethical theory of consequentialism, which states that anything can be judged as morally right or wrong based on its consequence.

projects.title: Implementing Blade Element Momentum Theory Numerically for Wind Turbines in Yawed Flow
projects.description:
Course: Rotor and Wake Aerodynamics
Grade: 7.5/10

Developing a Python script that implements BEMT in axial and yawed flow for Wind Turbines. The BEM code incorporated the Glauert corrections for heavily loaded rotors for the wind turbine case, and the Prandtl tip and root corrections. The airfoil used was the DU 95-W-180. 

Span-wise variations of axial and tangential induction were studied along with a host of other wind turbine characteristics.

projects.title: Mesh Interpolation and Mesh Deformation for Fluid Structure Interaction: A Numerical Study
projects.description:
Course: Numerical Fluid-Structure Interaction
Grade: 8/10

In FSI computations it is required that pressure loads are transmitted from the fluid side of the fluid-structure interface to the structural nodes on that interface. Once the motion of the structure has been determined, the motion of the fluid mesh points on the interface has to be imposed. 

When the meshes are non-matching, an interpolation/projection step has to be carried out to enable transfer of information between the two domains. Different methods exist to transfer data between non-matching meshes, such as nearest-neighbor interpolation, projection methods, and methods based on interpolation by splines.

projects.title: Quantifying power effects of a propeller on the longitudinal stability and control of an aircraft test model: An Experimental Simulation
projects.description:
Course: Experimental Simulations 
Grade: 7.5/10 

Traditionally the efficiency of a turbofan engine is improved by increasing the engine bypass ratio. This, however, comes with an engine weight and size penalty. Propellers are inherently more efficient than turbofan engines. This is achieved by getting rid of the engine shroud. On the other hand, the aerodynamic phenomenon is now more complicated and due to the absence of the shroud and the engine sound is unconfined. 

Due to the complex nature of the aerodynamic interactions, a numerical simulation becomes unfeasible, therefore, experimental simulations are an effective tool to understand the complex flow phenomenon at a relatively cheaper cost and with the added benefit of collecting data and validating some numerical models. Thus the objective is the perform an experimental simulation and use the data to understand aerodynamic properties.

contributors.headline: Environmental Engineer @ Van Oord | MSc. TU Delft
MSc Aerospace Engineering (Aerodynamics) at Technische Universiteit Delft

projects.title: The Discrete Geometric Conservation Law for Fluid Structure Interaction: A Numerical Study
projects.description:
Course: Numerical Fluid-Structure Interaction
Grade: 8/10

In fluid-structure interaction simulations, the fluid equations are solved on a deforming mesh. An often-used method for dealing with deforming meshes is the Arbitrary Lagrangian-Eulerian (ALE) approach, which allows the fluid dynamics equations to be solved on arbitrarily moving/deforming control volumes. When using the ALE approach, a Geometric Conservation Law (GCL) can be identified that ties the mesh deformation to mesh velocities, used in the governing equations. The GCL is investigated for a set of simple test problems.

projects.title: Prediction of Airfoil Self-Noise using Diffraction Theory
projects.description:
Course: Introduction to Aeroacoustics 

Mini project to predict airfoil self-noise using Amiet's diffraction theory and implementing Goody's, Rozenberg's, Kamruzzaman's, and Lee's surface spectra models. Airfoil self-noise is produced due to the interaction between the airfoil blade and the turbulence which is produced but the airfoils' own boundary layer and near wake. Effects of surface pressure disturbances and back scattering were also investigated. Boundary layer data was obtained from XFoil and the analysis was done using Python.

profile_positions.title: Environmental Engineer - Underwater Acoustics

profile_positions.description:
JIP is a project collaboration between TU Delft and EWT. 
The project focuses on distributed wind power in combination with other renewable generation systems and energy storage to identify and evaluate future viable business cases for Hybrid Renewable Energy System (HRES) models for future EWT business cases. The team performed a techno-economic assessment of HRES system designs resulting in 50% LCoE reduction.  Proposed business cases achieved a carbon emission reduction of 70-90%. Also coordinated stakeholder needs and expectations, incorporated feedback into project planning and delivery. Collaborated with TU Delft Faculty and industry experts to evaluate project scope and relevance to the market.

EWT Coaches: Ir. Mark Jonkhof, Manoj Pathak.
TU Delft Coaches: Ir. Michiel Zaayer, Dr. ir. Dominic von Terzi.
